posts.title: AngstromCTF 2020
posts.text: Only now I have time to put writing in order. It's the only good part of the quarantine time we live… This time I bring to you my point of view of the Angstrom CTF I've entered in march, from 14th to 19th. I tooked a bit more than the usual ctf’s but it worth it, mostly because I could learn a lot during the game. I think it was the first time I could reverse some stuff (3 challenges) using Ghidra and gdb - it was really cool! :smile: This ctf competition had Misc, Web, Crypto, Binary and Rev categories with 47 total challenges. During the five competition days I could manage to solve ten of them, and the eleventh I took the flag a few minutes after the end of the competition. Bad luck… I ended up in 592nd place with 575 points. You can view my complete writeup in my github repo. The organizers release a public repository with the solves for the challenges at https://hackmd.io/@ZX59lFiyRu6ODiM2rFw7Wg/ry5FDNeI8#

posts.title: HackTM CTF 2020
posts.text: To start february in the best way I managed to participated in a CTF to improve my forensics skills - the HackTM CTF (Quals) 2020. I ended in 253rd place out of 748 teams. Saddly, I only entered in the second day of the competition and only managed to solve 2 challenges. One easy and another one more complex. The first one was a kind of one-point-challenge and the other was a USB capture with some input devices communicating in. Recently, I did a similar challenge in HTB where I had to decode the keyboard inputs. In this challenge I had to extract a zip file with a text file inside, but firtly I needed to found the password that protects the zip file. The password was in the keyboard input… My walkthrought it's in my github repo.

posts.title: </ Hello World >
posts.text: Like programming, this is my first post here. I hope you enjoy my thoughts and feel free for share yours with me. Here I will have some content about cyber and stuff related to it. Enjoy! ;)
